Controversial former Tory MP Ann Widdecombe is to swap her home on Dartmoor for the confines of the Celebrity Big Brother house as the new series begins. She is the second housemate confirmed for the new series, according to the Mirror Online . 
Ann, who is 70 and lives near Haytor, will step into the house on Tuesday night as the 2018 series begins. Read More Ann Widdecombe on Brexit, Boris, Mogg, Trump, the NHS and why Anton should have replaced Bruce Forsyth on Strictly Come Dancing 
Known for her controversial and divisive opinions, the former Tory politician is pro-Brexit and has made it clear she isn't a fan of reality stars. During her time in parliament she opposed the legality of abortion, inflamed the LGBT community after voting against lowering the age of consent and gave her support for the re-introduction of the death penalty. 
Fans got the first clue that she was gearing up for the house after she was apparently spotted at a hotel near the Elstree studio. Read More Politician, Strictly Come Dancing star and top author Ann Widdecombe urges book lovers to use their libraries 
Torquay's own celebrity TV favourite Georgia Toffolo, winner of the recent series of I'm a Celebrity Get Me out Of Here!, Tweeted her own reaction. 
And it's not Ann's first bash at reality TV. She entertained viewers of Strictly Come Dancing in series 8 of the dancing show in 2010. She is well prepared for the publicity which will inevitably come with the CBB appearance. She said: "I’ve developed a thick skin over the years. You do something controversial in politics, you get all the criticism, then you become a minister and you get a lot more, and so it goes on, until eventually it’s water off a duck’s back." 
The 2018 Celebrity Big Brother will boast an all-woman line-up. Journalist Rachel Johnson has already been confirmed, and other names mentioned include transgender broadcaster India Willoughby, Tattoo Fixers' Paisley Billings, party girl Laura Simpson and Made in Chelsea star Louise Thompson.
